questions.question:
Question 1: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for 
ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia 
and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS). The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They 
are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the 
image below. Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation 
defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis. It is of two types: • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age. • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation 
exposure with poor prognosis Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both 
types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most 
frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cytogenetic change in children with myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
588 
Sold by @itachibot Monosomy 7 is the most common cytogenetic change seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) in 
children. 5q deletion is the most common cytogenetic change seen in MDS in adults. The del(5q) abnormality is the dominant clone in most cases of MDS. This involves the stem-cell 
compartment and hence occurs as an early or initiating event in disease pathogenesis.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of these histopathological findings would you not expect to see in patients with 
myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Pseudo–Pelger–Huet cells are seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and not Pelger–Huet 
cells. Pelger–Huet cells are seen in Pelger–Huet syndrome, which is due to mutations in the lamin 
B-receptor gene. It is a neutrophil differentiation disorder with leukocyte appearance as: • Dumbbell-shaped bilobed nuclei • Reduced number of nuclear segments • Coarse clumping of the nuclear chromatin In MDS, pseudo-Pelger Huet cells are seen due to abnormal nuclear budding i.e. neutrophils with 
only 2 nuclear lobes.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following bone marrow and peripheral blood findings is not seen in patients 
with myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Image 3 showing hypocellular bone marrow is not seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS.) In 
this condition, bone marrow is hypercellular. However, pancytopenia results from ineffective 
hematopoiesis. The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in MDS. 589 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, and heaviness in the left 
hypochondrium for 6 months. His hemogram and peripheral smear are given below. What is 
the most likely diagnosis? 578 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various 
sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the 
histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing garden party or college girl 
appearance. CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It 
occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene. Clinical features of CML: • Hypermetabolism • Fatigability • Weakness • Weight loss and anorexia • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing - • Splenomegaly • Mild hepatomegaly • Lymphadenopathy Hematological findings include: • Mild-to-moderate anemia • Leukocytosis 590 
Sold by @itachibot • Platelets - usually increased • DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, 
and basophils and blasts (>10%) Note: Convent girl appearance is seen in CLL.

questions.question: Question 6: What mutation results in Philadelphia chromosome?
questions.explanation:
Philadelphia chromosome results from t(9;22)(q34;q11). It is most commonly seen in chronic 
myeloid leukemia (CML). CML is due to the formation of a chimeric BCR-ABL gene or Philadelphia chromosome. This gene 
is derived from a reciprocal translocation (9;22)(q34;q11). The image given below shows the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome. This translocation can be identified on fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH). The image given below shows (9;22) translocation as seen on FISH. 591 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: Bone marrow biopsy in a patient shows pseudo-Gaucher cells. What is the most probable 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Psuedo-Gaucher cells are characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). These cells are 
scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm. Their presence indicates a 
good prognosis. Bone marrow findings in CML: • Markedly hypercellular marrow - increased maturing granulocytic precursors • Elevated eosinophils and basophils • Increased megakaryocytes - include small, dysplastic forms • Erythroid progenitors - normal or mildly decreased • Increased reticulin deposition • Overt marrow fibrosis - rare early in the course • Pseudo-Gaucher cells • Sea blue histiocytes The image given below shows pseudo-Gaucher cells in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). 592 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 60-year-old woman with fever and splenomegaly was diagnosed to have chronic myeloid 
leukemia. She was started on imatinib therapy. After a few months of therapy, she had 
persistent progressive splenomegaly and fatigue. Which of the following will not be seen in 
this phase?
questions.explanation:
In a patient with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), progressive splenomegaly, not responsive to 
therapy is suggestive of an accelerated phase. In this phase, blasts are <20% in blood or 
marrow. Diagnosis of an accelerated phase of CML requires one of the following criteria: • Persistent or increasing WBC (>10 × 109/L), unresponsive to therapy • Persistent or increasing splenomegaly, unresponsive to therapy • Persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 × 109/L), unresponsive to therapy • Persistent thrombocytopenia (<100 × 109/L) unrelated to therapy • 20% or more basophils in the peripheral blood • 10%-19% blasts in the peripheral blood or bone marrow • Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities in Ph+ cells at diagnosis that include “major route” 
abnormalities (second Ph, trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q, trisomy 19), complex karyotype, or 
abnormalities of 3q26.2 • Any new clonal chromosomal abnormality in Ph+ cells that occurs during therapy

questions.question: Question 9: What is the percentage of blast cells in the blast phase of CML?
questions.explanation:
In the blast phase of chronic myeloid leukemia, there are >20% blasts in the bone marrow. The 3 phases of CML are: • Chronic phase is the most common presentation. It is characterized by: 593 
Sold by @itachibot • Leukocytosis - bimodal distribution with higher proportions of mature segmented neutrophils 
and myelocytes • Blast cells <10% • Increased basophils and eosinophils • Monocytosis <3% • Accelerated phase occurs in 50% of the patients who present with increasing anemia, 
thrombocytopenia and splenomegaly. It is characterized by: • Blast count 10-19% • Basophilia >20% • Blast phase in CML occurs in an average of 3 years after the diagnosis. It is characterized by: • Large foci or clusters of blasts on the bone marrow biopsy >20%. • Presence of extramedullary blastic infiltrates (e.g., myeloid sarcoma or chloroma)

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is not seen in a patient with Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative 
syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia?
questions.explanation:
Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia (previously named as 
atypical chronic myeloid leukemia) shows minimal absolute basophilia, i.e., <2% of total WBCs. Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia is a leukemic 
disorder having features of both myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative features at the time of 
diagnosis. It is classified under the WHO 5th edition (2022) MDS/MPN category. Characteristics of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia: • Peripheral blood leukocytosis with an increased number of mature and immature neutrophils • Prominent dysgranulopoiesis • Philadelphia chromosome-negative • Neutrophil precursors (promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes) >10% of WBCs • Minimal absolute basophilia <2% of WBCs • Absolute monocytosis <10% of WBCs • Hypercellular bone marrow • <20% blasts in blood and bone marrow • Thrombocytopenia Differences between CML and myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with 
neutrophilia: Feature 
CML 
Myelodysplastic/Myeloprolife 
rative syndrome (MDS/MPN) 
with neutrophilia BCR-ABL gene 
Present 
Absent 594 
Sold by @itachibot Feature 
CML 
Myelodysplastic/Myeloprolife 
rative syndrome (MDS/MPN) 
with neutrophilia Basophilia 
Present 
<2% <2%<5% 
<20%<20% Myeloblasts in peripheral blo

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following patients will have a decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score?

options.a: A 65-year-old-man with garden party appearance on peripheral smear
options.b: A 50-year-old man with Reed Sternberg cells on LN biopsy
options.c: A 35-year-old woman with Hb level of 23 g/dL
options.d: A 43-year-old woman with smudge cells on peripheral smear

questions.explanation:
Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) i.e. 
garden party appearance on peripheral smear.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following does not cause relative polycythemia?
questions.explanation:
High altitude produces absolute polycythemia and not relative polycythemia. Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in 
the hemoglobin level (> 16 ±2 g/dL). It is 2 types: • Relative - hemoconcentration due to decreased plasma volume • Absolute - increase in the total red cell mass Causes of relative polycythemia include: • Dehydration - deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, excessive use of diuretics • Gaisböck syndrome - stress polycythemia where affected individuals are usually hypertensive, 
obese, and anxious Causes of absolute polycythemia include: • Primary - intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors • Polycythemia vera • Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations • Secondary - red cell progenitors responding to increased levels of erythropoietin • Compensatory due to cyanotic heart and lung disease, high altitude • Paraneoplastic erythropoietin secreting tumours Note: In dengue hemorrhagic fever, increased vascular permeability causes plasma leakage and 
volume loss. Hence, relative polycythemia is seen. 595 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - 
Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, 
myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should 
be:

options.d: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Hence, erythropoietin 
levels (EPO) are estimated next, to differentiate between primary or secondary polycythemia. 
Based on EPO levels: • Primary polycythemia - normal/ decreased • Secondary polycythemia - increased Options A and B: JAK 2 mutation and Philadelphia chromosome analysis is only done as a last 
resort. Option D: Bone marrow estimation with reticulin is done for myelofibrosis which can be seen in 
the spent/ late stage of the disease. However, peripheral smear findings are not suggestive of 
primary myelofibrosis. Leukoerythroblastic reaction with dacrocytes is seen in myelofibrosis.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 24-year-old woman who presented with aquagenic pruritis had a Hb level of 20 g/dL. Her 
lab investigations are given below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera. Hepatic failure is not seen in this 
condition. Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase 
JAK2. In this condition, clonal erythrocytosis occurs autonomously i.e. independent of 
erythropoietin. Clinical features of polycythemia vera: • Headache • Hypertension • Dizziness • Intense pruritis, aquagenic pruritis • Peptic ulcer • Venous thrombosis - Budd-Chiari syndrome (hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, stroke, 
myocardial infarction • Minor hemorrhages - epistaxis, gum bleeding Laboratory findings in polycythemia vera: • Panmyelosis - increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets • Low erythropoietin • Elevated hematocrit • Hyperuricemia Complications of polycythemia vera: • Myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis - spent /late phase • Acute myeloid leukemia 596 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A 63-year-old woman complains about throbbing pain over both palms. Her examination 
findings and lab reports are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 581 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The image showing 
erythematous hands is suggestive of erythromelalgia. Essential thrombocythemia (essential thrombocytosis) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is 
associated with mutations that increase JAK-STAT signaling. WHO criteria for diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia: • Major criteria - • Platelet count 450 × 109/L • Bone marrow biopsy showing proliferation mainly of the megakaryocyte lineage with increased 
numbers of enlarged, mature megakaryocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei • Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 chronic myeloid leukemia, PV, PMF, myelodysplastic 
syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation • Minor criteria - the presence of a clonal marker or absence of evidence for reactive 
thrombocytosis Diagnosis of ET requires meeting all 4 major criteria or the first 3 major criteria and the minor 
criterion Option A: Polycythemia vera can also present with erythromelalgia. However, it also presents with 
increased Hb levels. Option C: Fibrosis (not reticulin fibrils) is seen in bone marrow biopsy of primary myelofibrosis. Option D: WBC counts are increased in leukemoid reactions.

questions.question:
Question 16: Patients with which of the following conditions do not have a leukoerythroblastic picture on 
peripheral smear?
questions.explanation:
Leukoerythroblastic picture is not seen in patients with thalassemia as it is a hemoglobinopathy 
and does not involve myeloid precursors. Abnormal presence of immature precursors of blood in the peripheral blood smear is called 
leukoerythroblastosis. Findings include: • Nucleated red cells • Dacryocytes (or teardrop RBC) - formed due to damage to red cell membrane caused by fibrous 
tissue in the marrow • Immature cells of granulocytic series It occurs due to conditions causing marrow replacement like: • Primary myelofibrosis - fibrosis of bone marrow • Myelophthisic anemia - space occupying lesions of bone marrow 597 
Sold by @itachibot • Gauchers disease • Spent phase of polycythemia vera The image given below shows a leukoerythroblastic blood picture with nucleated RBCs, tear-drop 
cells, and immature myeloid cells.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not included under MDS/MPN overlap syndromes?

options.c: MDS/MPN with SF31B mutation and thrombocytosis

questions.explanation:
Myelodysplastic syndrome/ myeloproliferative neoplasm (MDS/MPN) overlap syndromes are a 
group of chronic clonal myeloid malignancies in which there are features of both MDS and MPN 
at the time of presentation. According to the 5th edition WHO classification (2022), it includes: • Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia • MDS/MPN with neutrophilia (previously atypical chronic myeloid leukemia) • MDS/MPN with SF31B mutation and thrombocytosis • MDS/MPN not otherwise specified

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following is not compatible with a diagnosis of chronic myelomonocytic 
leukemia?

options.c: More than 20% blasts in blood or bone marrow
options.d: Absent or minimal dysplasia in myeloid lineages

questions.explanation:
More than 20% of blasts in the blood or bone marrow are not compatible with a diagnosis of 
chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML). In this condition, blasts are less than 20%. WHO 5th edition diagnostic criteria (2022_for chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) 
include: Prerequisite criteria: • 1. Persistent absolute (0.5 × 109/ L) and relative (10%) peripheral blood monocytosis. • 2. Blasts constitute <20% of the cells in the peripheral blood and bone marrow. 598 
Sold by @itachibot • 3. Not meeting diagnostic criteria of chronic myeloid leukemia or other myeloproliferative 
neoplasms (MPN).b • 4. Not meeting diagnostic criteria of myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with tyrosine kinase fusions.c Supporting criteria: • 1. Dysplasia involving 1 myeloid lineage.d • 2. Acquired clonal cytogenetic or molecular abnormality. • 3. Abnormal partitioning of peripheral blood monocyte subsets.e Pre-requisite criteria must be present in all cases: • If monocytosis is  1 × 109/ L: one or more supporting criteria must be met. • If monocytosis is 0.5 and <1 × 109/ L: supporting criteria 1 and 2 must be met. Subtype criteria: • Myelodysplastic CMML (MD-CMML): WBC < 13 × 109/L • Myeloproliferative CMML (MP-CMML): WBC  13 × 109/L a. Blasts and blast equivalents include myeloblasts, monoblasts, and promonocytes. b. MPN with monocytosis can mimic CMML. In these instances, a documented history of MPN 
excludes CMML. The presence of MPN features in the bone marrow and/or a high burden of 
MPN-associated mutations (JAK2, CALR, or MPL) tends to support MPN with monocytosis rather 
than CMML. c. Criteria for myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with tyrosine kinase fusions should be specifically 
excluded in cases with eosinophilia. d. Morphologic dysplasia should be present in 10% of cells of a hematopoietic lineage in the bone 
marrow. e. Based on the detection of increased classical monocytes (>94%) in the absence of known 
active autoimmune diseases and/or systemic inflammatory syndromes.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 2-year-old boy with Noonan syndrome presents with hepatosplenomegaly and 
lymphadenopathy. You are suspecting juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. Which of the 
following is not seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
HbF levels are increased in juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), not Hb A2. JMML is a hematopoietic stem cell-derived myeloproliferative neoplasm of early childhood. It is 
one of the myeloproliferative neoplasms. It is associated with mutations in the RAS pathway. 
Neurofibromatosis 1, Noonan syndrome, and trisomy 8 mosaicism can predispose to this 
condition. Aggressive types include PTPN11 mutation and neurofibromatosis type 1. WHO diagnostic guidelines of JMML: *Germline mutation (indicating Noonan syndrome) needs to be excluded. It is associated with a poor prognosis and only a few patients undergo spontaneous regression. 599 
Sold by @itachibot Category I (Mandatory):Clini 
cal and hematologic features Category II:Genetic (only 1 re 
quired) Category III: Category I + the 
se findings: Somatic mutation inPTPN11 
* orKRAS* orNRAS*Clinical d 
iagnosis of Neurofibromatosi 
s type 1 or NF1 mutationGer 
mline CBL mutation Hemoglobin F increased for 
ageMyeloid or erythroid prec 
ursors on the peripheral bloo 
d smearHypersensitivity to G 
M-CSF by colony assay and S 
TAT5 hyperphosphorylationT 
hrombocytopenia with hyper 
cellular bone marrow SplenomegalyPeripheral bloo 
d monocyte count 1 × 109/L 
Blast percentage in periphera 
l blood and bone marrow <2 
0%No Philadelphia chromos 
ome (BCR/ABL1 rearrangeme 
nt)Exclusion of KMT2A muta 
tion

questions.question: Question 20: JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with
questions.explanation:
Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase 
JAK2. A mutation in JAK2, a key member of the cytokine intracellular signaling pathway, can be found 
in 90–95% of patients with polycythemia vera. It is characterized by : • Increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis) • Low erythropoietin levels and elevated hematocrit • Blood viscosity and sludging lead to both thrombosis and bleeding. • Headache, dizziness, hypertension, dizziness, venous thrombosis (Budd Chiari syndrome due to 
hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, and stroke. • Intense pruritus especially aquagenic pruritus • Peptic ulceration, hyperuricemia • 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years ->Myelofibrosis and extensive 
extramedullary hematopoiesis, • PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients. Primary myelofibrosis • Marrow fibrosis associated with extramedullary hemopoiesis in the spleen. • Activating mutation in JAK2 (more commonly) or MPL. • Presence of neoplastic megakaryocytes, which are responsible for the release of fibrogenic 
factors like PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) and TGF- . • Bone marrow aspiration yields dry tap due to fibrosis of the bone marrow. • So, bone marrow biopsy is the investigation of choice, which shows the presence of 
hypocellularity with increased deposition of reticulin inside the marrow, abnormal 
megakaryocytes and the characteristic finding of dilated marrow sinusoids. • Blood shows mild leukocytosis, decreased Hb and hematocrit levels, and elevated LAP scores. • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 5% to 20% of cases. 600 
Sold by @itachibot Essential thrombocytosis (ET) may also be associated with JAK2, MPL, or CALR mutations. • Essential thrombocytosis (ET) is often associated with activating point mutations in JAK2 (50% 
of cases) or MPL (5% to 10% of cases), a receptor tyrosine kinase that is normally activated by 
thrombopoietin. • In addition, recent DNA sequencing studies have revealed that most of the remaining cases have 
mutations in calreticulin (CALR), a protein with several functions in the endoplasmic reticulum 
and the cytoplasm. Since JAK2 and calreticulin mutations are mutually exclusive, it is 
hypothesized that the calreticulin mutations also increase JAK-STAT signaling through 
mechanisms that are currently unknown. CML is the consequence of the balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t[9;22]). PV, PMF, and ET are characterized by driver mutations that directly or indirectly constitutively 
activate JAK2, a tyrosine kinase essential for the function of the erythropoietin 
andthrombopoietin receptors and also utilized by granulocyte colony stimulating factor receptor.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following patients is least likely to have leukemoid reaction?

options.d: A patient with acute myocardial infarction

questions.explanation:
Myocardial infarction does not cause leukemoid reaction. Leukemoid reaction is defined as persistent leukocytosis above 50000 cells /mm3, where the 
cause is other than leukemia. Causes of leukemoid reaction include: • Severe infections • Malignancy • Severe hemorrhage • Acute hemolysis • Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) • Asplenia • Diabetic ketoacidosis

questions.question: Question 22: Electron microscopic picture of which of the following conditions is shown below?
questions.explanation:
The given electron microscopy image shows tennis racket shaped Birbeck granules. These 
granules are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. These granules are pentalaminar tubules with dilated terminal ends. This gives a characteristic 
tennis racket appearance on electron microscopy. They contain the protein langerin (CD207). The image given below shows the Birbeck granules as seen on electron microscopy. 601 
Sold by @itachibot On peripheral smear, the proliferating Langerhans cells are characterised by: • Abundant vacuolated cytoplasm • Vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds - coffee bean nuclei The image given below shows Langerhans cells with coffee bean nuclei and moderately abundant 
pale cytoplasm mixed with a few eosinophils. Note: Tennis racket cells in light microscopy seen in sarcoma botryoides.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following is not a histiocytic neoplasm?
questions.explanation:
Rosai–Dorfman disease is not a histiocytic neoplasm. It is sinus histiocytosis with massive 
lymphadenopathy. 602 
Sold by @itachibot WHO classification of histiocytic/ hematolymphoid neoplasm 2016 includes the following: • Histiocytic sarcoma • Langerhans cell histiocytosis • Langerhans cell sarcoma • Indeterminate dendritic cell tumour • lnterdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma • Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma • Fibroblastic reticular cell tumour • Disseminated juvenile xanthogranuloma • Erdheim–Chester disease

questions.question:
Question 24: You are suspecting Langerhans cell histiocytosis in a child with an enlarging scalp lesion. 
Which of the following markers will you test to confirm your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: S-100 is a marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Tumour cells in this condition typically express the following: • HLA-DR • S-100 • CD1a

questions.question:
Question 25: A 5-year-old girl is brought to you by her father, who states that the girl is drinking a lot of 
water lately. Physical examination reveals exophthalmos. Further workup shows the presence 
of multiple lytic bone lesions involving her calvarium and the base of her skull. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hand–Schüller–Christian disease. Langerhans cell histiocytosis presents as multiple clinicopathological entities: 1. Hand–Schüller–Christian disease is a multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell 
histiocytosis. It usually affects young children. It is characterized by the triad of: • Diabetes insipidus (excessive thirst) - involvement of the posterior pituitary stalk of the 
hypothalamus • Exophthalmos • Multiple lytic bone lesions It usually undergoes spontaneous regression. It is treated with local excision or irradiation. 2. Letterer–Siwe disease is a multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It occurs most 
frequently before 2 years of age, but occasionally affects adults. It is characterized by the following features: • Cutaneous lesions, resembling a seborrheic eruption - caused by infiltrates of Langerhans cells 
over the front and back of the trunk and on the scalp 603 
Sold by @itachibot • Hepatosplenomegaly • Lymphadenopathy • Pulmonary lesions • Destructive osteolytic bone lesions • Due to marrow infiltration - anemia, thrombocytopenia, predisposition to recurrent infections 
(otitis media and mastoiditis) Treatment involves intensive chemotherapy. This condition is fatal if left untreated. 3. Eosinophilic granuloma is a unifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is characterized 
by the proliferation of Langerhans cells admixed with variable numbers of eosinophils, 
lymphocytes, plasma cells, and neutrophils. These lesions occur in the following sites: • Medullary cavities of bones - most commonly the calvarium, ribs, and femur • Skin • Lungs • Stomach Bone lesions can manifest as: • Asymptomatic • Pain • Tenderness • Pathologic fractures. Treatment is by local excision or irradiation. 4. Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis is most often seen in adult smokers. It regresses 
spontaneously upon cessation of smoking.

questions.question:
Question 26: The X-ray of a 65-year-old man is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and 
urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image showing a solitary punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim 
with a beveled edge appearance, along with the age of the patient with history of normal 
hematological and urinary tests is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature 
dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions. It can also infiltrate the skin (of 
the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system.

questions.question:
Question 27: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done using the instrument given in 
the image below?

options.c: Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position
options.d: Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease

questions.explanation:
604 
Sold by @itachibot The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not in itself a 
contraindication for bone marrow biopsy. However, a platelet count >20,000 is ensured for 
safety purposes. Indications of bone marrow biopsy: • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin, suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections, 
or granulomatous diseases Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy: • Severe hemophilia • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy • Severe bleeding disorders Procedure for bone marrow biopsy: Prone or lateral position is chosen for the procedure. Posterior superior iliac spine is identified. 
After disinfection and local anaesthesia, the patient is asked to inhale slowly through the nose and 
exhale slowly through the mouth to relieve anxiety .The needle is inserted and rotated on its axis. On reaching the desired depth, the stylet is removed and needle is advanced. The needle is rotated 
in the opposite direction to loosen the specimen. It is then withdrawn using the same rotational 
movement.

questions.question: Question 28: Blood examination shows pancytopenia, which can be correct?
questions.explanation:
605 
Sold by @itachibot Megaloblastic anemia (hypocellular phase), hairy cell leukemia, and hypocellular MDS can show 
pancytopenia. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is not associated with pancytopenia. Causes of pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow: • Acquired aplastic anemia • Hypocellular myelodysplastic syndrome • Rare aleukemic leukemia • Some acute lymphoid leukemia • Rare lymphomas of bone marrow • Copper deficiency Causes of pancytopenia with cellular bone marrow: • Myelodysplastic syndromes • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) • Hypersplenism • B12, folate deficiency, Copper deficiency • Myelofibrosis • Aleukemic leukemia • HIV, Brucellosis, Leishmaniasis, Tuberculosis Sepsis • Myelophthisis • Bone marrow lymphoma • Sarcoidosis • Hairy cell leukemia

questions.question:
Question 29: Which of the following conditions will have the least chances of a dry tap on bone marrow 
aspiration? 586 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Follicular lymphoma is the least likely cause of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration. Causes of dry tap are: • Metastatic carcinoma infiltration • Chronic myeloid leukemia • Myelofibrosis • Hairy cell leukemia • Acute leukemia • Hodgkin's lymphoma • AML- M7 606 
Sold by @itachibot Causes of pancytopenia with cellular marrow are: Primary disease of marrow- • Myelodysplastic syndrome • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) • Myelofibrosis • Aleukemic leukemia • Myelophthisis • Bone marrow lymphoma • Hairy cell leukemia Secondary to systemic disease- • SLE, sarcoidosis • B12, folate deficiency • Copper deficiency • Hypersplenism • Alcohol • HIV infection, TB • Brucellosis, leishmaniasis Note: Although marrow is hypercellular in CML, MDS etc., extensive marrow fibrosis (rare) has 
been proposed to account for a dry tap on bone marrow biopsy. 607 
Sold by @itachibot Leukopenia, Leukocytosis and Lymphadenitis
